body: This is based on an existence implementation so you can merge this PR and I can create a ticket for test or I can add test implementation to this PR?

This is an initial PR due to I get that error when I run ant check-forbidden-apis:

+1 to commit this, and add tests separately.
ACK +1 from me
@kamaci  can you please squash your commits?
@lewismc I've reset to the valid version. It should be fine now.
Also looking forward to this. Anything I can do to help get it in 1.12?

This looks dynamite.
Can you also update the relevant properties within default.properties e.g. the Javadoc links for Lucene, Solr, etc? An example of this can be seen within the 2.x default.properties.

Thank you very much for this patch @naegelejd

I added the relevant properties to `default.properties` and included corresponding `<link>s` for the JavaDoc in `build.xml`. I also updated the Solrj dependency from 5.4.1 -> 5.5.0 to match the Lucene version change.

Since this changes the version of a handful of dependencies, should it correspond to a separate JIRA issue, or is it OK that it's attached to NUTCH-2234? I'm thinking, for example, when someone adds this fix to `CHANGES.txt`, the ticket description doesn't match the actual fix (i.e. this upgrades Elasticsearch to 2.3.3, not 2.1.1, etc.).

Hi @naegelejd dynamite

> I added the relevant properties to default.properties and included corresponding <link>s for the 
> JavaDoc in build.xml. I also updated the Solrj dependency from 5.4.1 -> 5.5.0 to match the Lucene
> version change. 

Excellent thank you

> Since this changes the version of a handful of dependencies, should it correspond to a separate JIRA issue, 

I don't think so no. I think it it best if we adopt a policy that these are kept in sync (to the best of our ability) from now on. This has been an issue previously with dependencies like httpclient, etc. however from now on dependency management should be better handled. I think what you are doing is the right way to go.

> or is it OK that it's attached to NUTCH-2234? I'm thinking, for example, when someone addsthis fix to CHANGES.txt, the ticket description doesn't match the actual fix (i.e. this upgrades Elasticsearch to 2.3.3, not 2.1.1, etc.).

we don't need to add anything to changes.txt apart from the Jira release report. The release announcement is a different kettle of fish and should be more user friendly. 

One thing on the side here. Every pull request and commit message should reflect the Jira tickey title. This way all of our Github hooks work flawlessly. This way it also makes it much easier to track more complex issues like this one where possibly more than one feature is being touched at any one time.

Hi @naegelejd  @chrismattmann the PR has conflicts.
I was working on a patch but got up ended and worked on other things. I am now working on a full codebase Hadoop API upgrade... which is taking time in between the pub.
1) I acknowledge my neglect for this issue
2) .Our tests are pretty lacking on this issue, that was the problem. I absolutely agree with Markus Jelsma we need to have tests here as this is a patch which affects a critical workflow.

@naegelejd are you able to rebase and provide a test? If not then I can go back to my branch.
I can't promise anything. I'm not familiar with mrunit yet but I may find time soon to continue work on this in addition to a handful of other issues I'm hoping to fix or have merged soon.

Pull patch, ran tests and demo crawl all good. Readsegs, read db, dump and
index to Solr all good.

I'm going to be very blunt and ask why this was committed in its current state. Now I understand why I had to jump through hoops to upgrade the Elasticsearch dependency for both #118 and [NUTCH-2287](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NUTCH-2287).

Lucene dependencies should not be in `ivy/ivy.xml` and I really don't think the `scoring-similarity` plugin should be relying on the dependencies of the `indexer-elastic` plugin.

I'd be happy to fix this if someone takes it seriously and merges it soon.

> I'm going to be very blunt and ask why this was committed in its current state. Now I understand why I had to jump through hoops to upgrade the Elasticsearch dependency for both #118 and NUTCH-2287.

@naegelejd, the implementation works and was an initial attempt to sync lucene-core (and transitive deps) across the Nutch plugin and core codebase. Lets work on getting #118 in there for the time being. The dependency management issue is nothing new. It is however something which can be improved. 

> Lucene dependencies should not be in ivy/ivy.xml 

I agree

> and I really don't think the scoring-similarity plugin should be relying on the dependencies of the indexer-elastic plugin.

Well, this is one way we can sync dependencies. That is the goal however I agree that the direct dependency is not optimal.

> I'd be happy to fix this if someone takes it seriously and merges it soon.

Lets revisit your patch for #118 first. We can then come back to this. Thanks for your patience!

@kamaci Have you tried again recently? If you have and the Avro issue is persistent then maybe this has to do with how Avro is defined within ivy.xml?

@sjwoodard actually, I've reverted this commit. In httpclient 4.4.1 the SystemDefaultHttpClient is deprecated
http://hc.apache.org/httpcomponents-client-4.4.x/httpclient/apidocs/index.html?org/apache/http/impl/client/SystemDefaultHttpClient.html
You are advised to use the HttpClientBuilder instead. 
Can you please update the patch accordingly? Thanks.
http://hc.apache.org/httpcomponents-client-4.4.x/httpclient/apidocs/index.html?org/apache/http/impl/client/HttpClientBuilder.html

Sorry, I didn't notice it was deprecated. Using HttpClientBuilder doesn't work because it returns a CloseableHttpClient, which was introduced in HttpClient 4.3 (same version they deprecated SystemDefaultHttpClient). Hadoop is still using HttpClient 4.2.5, which doesn't have CloseableHttpClient. 

So, I think using SystemDefaultHttpClient is the cleanest way to bridge the two HttpClient versions. Otherwise, Hadoop 2.8 will fix this.

As an alternative, users with this issue can upgrade use these Hadoop 2.8 patches to upgrade their HttpClient:
- https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP-12767
- https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HADOOP-11859

I'll leave this branch up as a guide for other users with this issue.
LGTM is this compatible with the Nutch Python interface, Sujen? Can we have an associated PR there. Also we should make some Nutch-Python tests and integrate with Travis-CI like we did Tika Python.

Thanks!
👍 from me please commit!

Hello Lewis,

Here was that plugin I worked on a few months ago; unfortunately, I was running into methodNotFound errors using the Jest dependency. It turned out to be a versioning conflict between several apache http libraries (httpclient, httpcore, httpcore-nio). I tried adding them to the plugin's ivy.xml file without any success. However, after I added them to the root ivy.xml file, I'm no longer seeing these errors. 

Is there a better way around this issue besides modifying the root ivy.xml file? And if I resolve it, is there any chance this PR would get merged?

Thanks!

Real-world testing continued over two [Common Crawl](http://commoncrawl.org/) monthly crawls.
There is still one problem: if data is moved from one file system to another this fails with the current patch. E.g., CrawlDbMerger creates a temporary output `crawldb-merge-xxxx` on the default file system (HDFS). Calling `fs.rename(...)` (`fs` being the output file system, here s3a) then fails:

```
16/07/22 18:13:42 ERROR s3a.S3AFileSystem: rename: src not found hdfs://ip-10-185-27-174.ec2.internal/user/ubuntu/crawldb-merge-2766889
```

Not sure whether there is a solution for cross file system moves/renames or whether we have to create temporary output only as subdir of the output path (as done by many other Nutch tools).

Ok, "it's not possible to run `hdfs dfs -mv` crossing different file systems" [[1](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34512596/how-does-hdfs-mv-command-work)]. The only solution is to write temporary output to the file system of the final output. Then it can be moved without any problems to the final destination.

Hi @lewismc, I've refactored my branch to try to resolve all the issues: 
1. I've added the Apache License as comments to the howto_upgrade_es.txt
2. I've installed an Eclipse Formatting Plugin into Intellij, and have run it on the plugin; everything is now 2 spaces indented
3. I've refactored all 'e.printstacktrace()' calls to be Logger.error() calls instead (sorry for the inconsistency, my IDE autogenerates these for try catch blocks, and I forgot to replace some of them with Logger.error() calls)
4. I've changed all Logger method calls to use parameterized logging
5. I've also changed the RuntimeException to be an IllegalStateException instead, since the host and port information must be provided (and it would be an illegal state to proceed without them)
6. I've also fixed the package.info to mention the RESTful nature of the plugin
7. I'm still sort of confused on what the setConf method was supposed to do, but I've refactored it to mimic the other elastic index writer plugin; I'm not sure how the Conf object passed in this method differs from the JobConf object passed in the "open" method, so I have the open method handling the class member initialization (since that's what the other plugins seem to do). 

The plugin also does support authentication! If you've enabled the https option in nutch-site.xml, and the username and password fields are both not empty, the plugin will attempt to use them to perform a basic-auth request. I've also deleted one of the todo's since I've included the code to perform NoOp verification on hostnames (if the option is set to true in nutch-site) as well as trusting self-signed certs. I've also created the JIRA issue as requested: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NUTCH-2304 and I've set the External Issue URL to point to this pull request's associated issue. 

Thanks for reviewing my pull request!
Please let me know if there are any other changes I should fix; I'll be happy to commit them the next weekend I'm free.
+1 Lgtm!

- this would mean to have all libs from all plugins on the classpath. In consequence, we would have to make sure that there are absolutely no conflicts between all dependencies.

Excellent points Seb. Some suggestions below

On Sep 25, 2016 2:53 AM, "Sebastian Nagel" notifications@github.com wrote:

> -1
> 
> this would mean to have all libs from all plugins on the classpath.

Your right this is not good as several plugins may not be being used in The
deployment. Maybe we should look into removing the unused plugins from the
copy command when we copy from /build to /runtime. That would solve the
issue you've pointed out. Wdyt?

In consequence, we would have to make sure that there are absolutely no
conflicts between all dependencies.

Is this a bad thing? Imho it is a good thing. It is possibly a naive
position to assume that we can obtain zero conflicts.

> this solution would have only effect in local mode but not for
> distributed mode where plugins and their dependencies are in the job file
> Correct. That is another issue which has not been addressed yet.
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> 
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

The advantage of the current implementation and the plugin class loader: two independent plugins can have conflicting library versions as dependencies. There may be still conflicts between "base" libs and plugin dependencies, see https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NUTCH-2316 for such an issue.

To add only libs from activated plugins to the class path would only make conflicts less probable. But we allow users to use any combination of available plugins, so sooner or later we see a conflict as a Jira issue. Also making the build use a runtime configuration such as the property `plugin.includes` would violate the idea that users always can deploy their configuration by just placing the customized nutch-site.xml in a folder which comes early on the classpath. 

> In consequence, we would have to make sure that there are absolutely no conflicts between all dependencies. Is this a bad thing? Imho it is a good thing. It is possibly a naive position to assume that we can obtain zero conflicts.

Yes, of course, it would be the best solution if we could resolve all conflicts. No question. But there are many conflicts, e.g., currently we have in runtime/local:

```
lib/httpclient-4.3.5.jar
plugins/lib-htmlunit/httpclient-4.3.4.jar
plugins/lib-selenium/httpclient-4.5.1.jar
plugins/indexer-solr/httpclient-4.4.1.jar
plugins/indexer-cloudsearch/httpclient-4.3.6.jar
```

And the right way would be: 1. resolve the conflicts and make sure that everything runs fine, 2. configure one global classpath. To get NUTCH-2316 resolved could be the first step of the first task.
